paragraphs.text: The Saadian dynasty ruled Morocco from 1549 to 1659 . The dynasty took full power in Morocco around 1554 . The Saadian Empire's establishment occurred over a half century through military action, eliminating the Wattasids . The Saadian dynasty saw some Turkish influence, starting from the reign of al-Mahdi and extending to al-Mançûr's era . The Saadian dynasty faced struggles against Spanish and Portuguese occupations in the north and the Ottomans in the east . The dynasty won the Battle of Oued Almakhazine (Battle of the Three Kings) . The Saadian empire reached its peak under al-Mançûr after 75 years of struggles and war . Ahmad al-Mansur reigned from 1578 to 1603 .

Ahmad al-Mansûr's death in 1603 triggered a civil war among his heirs, creating instability . The civil war occurred during a period of dynastic change, with the decline of the Saadian dynasty and the rise of the Alaouites . The internal political complexities of Morocco, including Saadian claimants, influenced the conflict . The Spanish occupation of Larache occurred during this period of Saadian decline .

sections.subtitle: The Succession Crisis and Key Players

paragraphs.text: Ahmad al-Mansur gained the throne after the Battle of the Three Kings on August 4, 1578 . Prior to becoming Sultan, Ahmad al-Mansur served as his brother Abd al-Malik's representative in Fez . Ahmad al-Mansur faced challenges from his son, Muhammad al-Shaykh al-Ma'mun, which prompted him to solidify ties with the ulema in Fez .

The death of Ahmad al-Mansûr in 1603 led to a power struggle between his sons, most notably Mawlây Zaydân and others . This succession crisis plunged Morocco into a period of intense conflict and fragmentation .

In 1610, Mawlây al-Shaykh, a son of Ahmad al-Mansûr, ceded Larache to Spain for military aid, a situation that fueled criticism of the Saadian dynasty . The Spanish occupied Larache from 1610-1689 . In 1610, Ibn Abî Mahallî led a group to conquer Sijilmasa, expelling the Saadian governor and army . Ibn Abî Mahallî, believing himself to be the Mahdi, conquered the Dra' region, crossed the Atlas, and seized Marrakech, the Saadian capital . On May 20, 1612, Ibn Abî Mahallî defeated Mawlây Zaydân and entered Marrakech, proclaiming a general pardon by the mandate of 'Muley Mahamete ben Abdala, King of all the Universe' .

Ibn Abî Mahallî's rule ended with his death in battle in 1613 against the supporters of Saadian Sultan Mawlây Zaydân, who then retook Marrakech . After his death, Ibn Abî Mahallî's head was displayed on the walls of Marrakech until it disintegrated . The faqîh Yahyâ b. Abd Allâh al-Hahî, a former friend of Ibn Abî Mahallî, led a campaign against him and ultimately defeated and killed Ibn Abî Mahallî in October 1613 (Ramadân 1022) . After defeating Ibn Abî Mahallî, Sîdî Yahyâ entered Marrakech and initially occupied the royal palace, but later withdrew, ceding the power back to Mawlây Zaydân . The Saadian sultan Mawlây Zaydân asked Sîdî Yahyâ for support against Ibn Abî Mahallî, which led to the battle in which Ibn Abî Mahallî was killed .
During the civil war between the Saadian brothers in the early 17th century, Morocco suffered droughts, famines, and a plague, further destabilizing the region .

The Spanish and Ottoman empires were both vying for influence in the region during this period . The Spanish maintained presidios in North Africa, such as Oran and Mers-el-Kébir, monitoring the Moroccan sultans . The Dutch and English governments were also engaged in diplomatic and trade discussions with Morocco . In 1610, Mawlây al-Shaykh ceded Larache to the spanish .

The Saadian Civil War weakened the dynasty and contributed to its eventual decline . The war also had a significant impact on Moroccan society, economy, and political landscape . The instability created by the conflict allowed for the rise of maraboutic figures and contributed to the fragmentation of the country . The Saadian dynasty ruled Morocco from the second half of the 16th century until 1659 . By 1670, the Arma pledged allegiance to the Alaouite sultans but revoked Moroccan suzerainty by the early eighteenth century .
